majors.major: ACCOUNTANCY, B.S. - Option in Information Systems
general_texts:
This agreement displays all lower-division courses required in the major: CSU Northridge courses on the left, approved (articulated) transfer courses to the right. General education (Cal-GETC or CSU Northridge GE) and upper-division courses are also required to complete the bachelor's degree.


Completion of all coursework listed in this agreement is not mandatory prior to admission. For CSU Northridge Undergraduate Admission Requirements, refer to Upper Division Transfer.


Some coursework may be satisfied by Advanced Placement exams completed in high school. Visit AP Credit for information. Additional information about the major is available in the CSUN University Catalog.


Questions regarding this agreement may be directed to: articulation@csun.edu.
CSU Northridge is an impacted campus. Refer to impaction information at: Transfer Impaction

Accountancy at CSU Northridge is an impacted major.


To become an Accountancy major, students must first complete the following Pre-Accountancy requirements:

  1. Completion of a minimum of 60 units of CSU-transferable college work.
  2. Completion of ACCT 220 and ENGL 205 (formerly BUS 205) or their equivalents (see below) with a grade of "B" or higher in each.
  3. Completion of ACCT 230, BLAW 280, ECON 160, ECON 161, IS 212, MATH 103 (or MATH 150A or MATH 255A) and SOM 120 (or MATH 140BUS) with a grade of “C” or higher in each.
  4. Completion of ACCT 350 at CSUN after transfer with a grade of "C" or higher.


To enroll in ACCT 350, students must obtain approval from the Admission Committee through an online application and have a total gpa and CSUN gpa or 3.2 or higher. A minimum gpa of 3.0 shall satisfy this requirement if seats are available. The CSUN gpa requirement does not apply to first-semester transfer students. After successfully completing all Pre-Accountancy requirements, student must file for a change of major to Accountancy.


It is highly recommended that all lower division major preparation courses including Statistics and Calculus be completed prior to transferring to CSU Northridge.

Engineering and Computer Science majors may follow CSU Northridge GE Plan instead of Cal-GETC.


Civil Engineering students are required to take courses in the following CSU GE areas: CSU Northridge GE

  • English Composition - Written Communication (3 units) = CSU GE Area 1A
  • Oral Communication (3 units) = CSU GE Area 1C
  • Mathematical Concepts and Quantitative Reasoning (3 units) = CSU GE Area 2
  • Arts (3 units) = CSU GE Area 3A
  • Humanities (3 units) = CSU GE Area 3B
  • Social and Behavioral Sciences (3 units) = CSU GE Area 4
  • Ethnic Studies (3 units) = CSU GE Area 6
  • CSUN Section F - Comparative Cultural Studies (3 units)
  • U.S. History and Government (6 units) = CSU US History, Constitution, and American Ideals


All other General Education requirements are met through completion of courses in the major. Students applying to majors in the College of Engineering and Computer Science do not need CSU GE-Critical Thinking 1B prior to admission.

Students may choose from two Biology pathways. The first is compatible with the AA-T in Kinesiology for options in Dance and Sport Studies:


  • General Biology/Lab
  • Human Anatomy/Laboratory Studies in Human Anatomy OR Human Anatomy for Health Sciences/Laboratory Studies in Human Anatomy
  • Human Physiology


OR


Recommended for students interested in pursuing graduate study in allied health-related programs such as physical therapy or medicine. This pathway is not compatible with the AA-T in Kinesiology since students may exceed 60 units after transfer to complete all requirements for the B.S. degree. Combined Anatomy and Physiology I and II course sequence from community college may be approved to substitute for Human Anatomy & Physiology I/Lab and Human Anatomy & Physiology II/ Lab:


  • Biological Principles I/Biology Laboratory I
  • Biological Principles II/Biology Laboratory II
  • Human Anatomy & Physiology I/Lab
  • Human Anatomy & Physiology II/Lab

This program satisfies CSUN General Education and Title V requirements. Students intending to transfer as Liberal Studies-Teacher Preparation options should NOT follow a CSU General Education Certification or Cal-GETC plan. Teacher Preparation Options are designed for future elementary or special education teachers. Students may select the Pre-Credential or the Integrated Teacher Education Program (ITEP)-Junior Option. The Pre-Credential Option provides a BA degree in Liberal Studies ONLY and is best suited for students who wish to enroll in a teaching credential program after they earn their bachelor's degree. The ITEP-Junior Option is for students who would like to earn their BA and credential simultaneously. All students begin in the Pre-Credential Option and take the classes below. To be admitted to ITEP-Junior Option, students must apply and gain admission to CSUN's Credential Program.


Students will select one Specialization from:

  • Language Arts or LSLA
  • Mathematics
  • History and Social Science
  • Sciences
  • Arts Integration
  • Childhood Studies
  • Sustainability and Environmental Humanities
  • Digital Humanities


Certain Specializations offer lower division courses, although not all do. Please refer to Specialization Courses in Group 18 Sections below:

  • Mathematics: Section A
  • History and Social Science, Track B: One from Section B
  • Sciences: One sequence from Section C; and one from Section D
  • Sustainability and Environmental Humanities: Section E
  • Digital Humanities: One from Section F


For additional information please visit Liberal Studies or call (818) 677-3300. Students should complete a Liberal Studies Workshop before attending CSUN. Students who have applied to CSUN and who have completed a workshop may schedule an appointment with an advisor after receiving an evaluation from the Liberal Studies office.

No grade lower than a “C” will be accepted on transfer from another institution to satisfy requirements for the major.

Engineering and Computer Science majors may follow CSU Northridge GE Plan instead of Cal-GETC.


Manufacturing Systems Engineering Students are required to take courses in the following CSU GE areas: CSU Northridge GE

  • English Composition - Written Communication (3 units) = CSU GE Area 1A
  • Oral Communication (3 units) = CSU GE Area 1C
  • Mathematical Concepts and Quantitative Reasoning (3 units) = CSU GE Area 2
  • Arts (3 units) = CSU GE Area 3A
  • Humanities (3 units) = CSU GE Area 3B
  • Social and Behavioral Sciences (3 units) = CSU GE Area 4
  • Ethnic Studies (3 units) = CSU GE Area 6
  • CSUN Section F - Comparative Cultural Studies (3 units)
  • U.S. History and Government (6 units) = CSU US History, Constitution, and American Ideals


All other General Education requirements are met through completion of courses in the major. Students applying to majors in the College of Engineering and Computer Science do not need CSU GE-Critical Thinking 1B prior to admission.

No grade lower than a “C” will be accepted on transfer from another institution to satisfy requirements for the major.

Engineering and Computer Science majors may follow CSU Northridge GE Plan instead of Cal-GETC.


Mechanical Engineering students are required to take courses in the following CSU GE areas: CSU Northridge GE

  • English Composition - Written Communication (3 units) = CSU GE Area 1A
  • Oral Communication (3 units) = CSU GE Area 1C
  • Mathematical Concepts and Quantitative Reasoning (3 units) = CSU GE Area 2
  • Arts (3 units) = CSU GE Area 3A
  • Humanities (3 units) = CSU GE Area 3B
  • Social and Behavioral Sciences (3 units) = CSU GE Area 4
  • Ethnic Studies (3 units) = CSU GE Area 6
  • CSUN Section F - Comparative Cultural Studies (3 units)
  • U.S. History and Government (6 units) = CSU US History, Constitution, and American Ideals


All other General Education requirements are met through completion of courses in the major. Students applying to majors in the College of Engineering and Computer Science do not need CSU GE-Critical Thinking 1B prior to admission.

Admission to CSUN and admission to the Radiologic Sciences program are separate procedures requiring two separate applications. Completion of the prerequisite criteria and acceptance to CSUN does not guarantee acceptance to the professional program because of limited clinical placements.


Non-current students may meet with the CSUN B.S. Radiologic Science advisor at least one year before their planned transfer to CSUN. An appointment may be made with a dedicated BSRS advisor directly through https://hsci.setmore.com/. The advisor will provide guidance and confirm prerequisite course and requirement progress/completion. Pre-professional courses must be completed or in-progress to be eligible for the Professional phase of the program. Refer to the Program website for additional information.


Mathematics: Either Pre-Calculus II or both (Pre-Calculus I + Trigonometry and Analytic Geometry) or equivalent transfer courses are accepted to satisfy the Mathematical Foundations for Non-Calculus Physics requirement.
